column3: During a press briefing, CDC Principal Deputy Director (Dr. Nirav Shah), agreed that milk processing and/or dairy operations are unlikely to explain the wastewater H5 signal in San Francisco. He noted two live bird markets where H5N1 infections have been detected as priority areas for investigation.

The CDC has made communication resources available, including for social media, related to the ongoing H5N1 outbreak. Resources include information for farm workers, individuals involved in livestock fairs, and those who may have been occupationally exposed.
HHS announced that Moderna has been awardede ~176M USD to develop pandemic influenza vaccines which would include H5N1.

column3: Colorado state health officials identify a human case of avian flu. The individual has recovered and the only reported symptom was conjunctivitis. column3: New paper in Nature suggests that the current H5N1 infecting dairy cattle may be able to infected cells in the human upper respiratory tract.This finding of the potential for the current H5N1 to infected the human upper respiratory tract raises the threat level of the current outbreak. However, this finding contradicts an earlier publication by the US CDC and is not supported by current epidemiological trends in humans.

Colorado is now reporting 5 human H5N1 cases. The individuals were workers at a poultry plant that had an active H5N1 outbreak. They had mild symptoms and recovered.

USDA confirms 161 positive dairy farms in thirteen states (Colorado (40), Idaho (30), Iowa (13), Kansas (4), Michigan (26), Minnesota (8), New Mexico (8), North Carolina (1), Ohio (1), South Dakota (5), Texas (22), Wyoming (1), Oklahoma (2))

An H5N1 genome collected from a human who was infected on a poultry farm in CO has been posted to GISAID. Preliminary analyses suggest that the virus had a dairy cow origin. This suggests that transmission likely occured from a dairy farm to the poultry farm to the farm worker.
